name: Stegosaurus
overview: Stegosaurus is a dinosaur currently documented from Late Jurassic (about 155-150 million years ago) in North America. Current interpretation suggests a herbivore feeding profile. It is typically classified as Stegosaurian ornithischian. Evidence quality for Stegosaurus is currently limited by specimen completeness and historical naming complexity. Dino-pedia tracks this taxon with conservative wording so future specimen-level studies can be integrated without overwriting uncertain claims.

externalAppearance.lips: Beaked front snout likely covered by keratin
externalAppearance.skin: Scaly with osteoderms and large dermal plates
externalAppearance.displayStructures: Large dorsal plates and thagomizer tail spikes
externalAppearance.coloration: Possible high-contrast display coloration on plates

huntingAndDiet.biteForce: Weak bite, relying on gut processing

physiology.stomachAcidPH: Adapted for plant digestion with long retention times
physiology.heartMass: Moderate for large herbivore body plan

growthStages.hatchling: Small spiked juvenile with reduced plate size
growthStages.oldAge: Plate wear and limb arthritis likely
growthStages.juvenile: Rapid plate growth and tail weapon development

reproduction.eggs: Likely small clutches in shallow nests

biomechanics.footStructure: Short forelimbs and longer hindlimbs with broad feet

pathologies.injuries: Tail spike trauma documented in some fossils

stats.tailWeight: Muscular tail used as active defense

funFacts: Its tail weapon is nicknamed the thagomizer
Plates were likely used for display and maybe thermoregulation
Stegosaurus had a very small skull relative to body size

behaviorAndConflict.socialBehavior: Could have formed small groups but may often have been dispersed feeders.
behaviorAndConflict.defensiveCombat: Used thagomizer tail spikes as primary close-range defense.
behaviorAndConflict.mainRivals: Large theropods such as Allosaurus likely targeted vulnerable individuals.
behaviorAndConflict.conflictEvidence: Some fossils suggest traumatic injuries consistent with predator encounters.

feedingPatterns.preferredPlants: Ferns, cycads, and soft conifer shoots in Jurassic floodplains.
feedingPatterns.dailyIntake: Likely fed for long periods daily on low-growing vegetation.
feedingPatterns.feedingStyle: Cropping and stripping plant matter with a narrow beaked snout.
feedingPatterns.digestiveStrategy: Relied on gut fermentation rather than heavy oral processing.

breedingAndNesting.parentalCare: Extended parental care is uncertain and currently weakly supported.
breedingAndNesting.nestingCycle: Likely seasonal nesting in shallow ground nests.
breedingAndNesting.hatchlingSurvival: Young likely relied on concealment until tail weapon development.
breedingAndNesting.courtship: Plate size and coloration may have served a visual role in mating displays.

extinctionContext.immediateEffects: Habitat restructuring likely reduced suitable feeding niches.
extinctionContext.timeline: Declined by the end of the Jurassic.
extinctionContext.legacy: A key case for understanding display structures in herbivorous dinosaurs.
extinctionContext.primaryDrivers: Long-term ecosystem turnover and competition changes.

fossilDiscoveryHistory.majorDiscoveries: Well-preserved plate and tail-spike material refined display/defense models.
fossilDiscoveryHistory.museumImpact: A cornerstone species in public understanding of Jurassic herbivores.
fossilDiscoveryHistory.researchMilestones: Plate vascularization studies examined thermoregulation hypotheses.
fossilDiscoveryHistory.firstFinds: Discovered during the late-19th-century Bone Wars.

locomotionAndAthletics.endurance: Adapted for prolonged low-speed browsing activity.
locomotionAndAthletics.maneuverability: Tail mobility provided rapid defensive arcs at close range.
locomotionAndAthletics.acceleration: Short bursts possible, but sustained speed was limited.

paleoecology.coexistingFauna: Coexisted with sauropods and major theropod predators.
paleoecology.nicheShifts: Juveniles probably selected more protected terrain than adults.
paleoecology.resourceDynamics: Feeding areas likely tracked seasonal moisture and plant growth.

sensoryAndIntelligence.cognition: Behavior likely centered on defensive response and routine feeding patterns.
sensoryAndIntelligence.smell: Olfaction probably aided foraging and conspecific recognition.
sensoryAndIntelligence.hearing: Likely sensitive to low and mid-range frequencies in open habitats.
sensoryAndIntelligence.vision: Likely relied on broad peripheral awareness to detect approaching predators.

researchContext.evidenceBase: Stegosaurus is represented by published fossil material, but completeness and diagnostic overlap can limit high-confidence biological reconstruction.
researchContext.currentLimits: Several ecological and life-history traits remain inferential rather than directly measured for this taxon.
researchContext.nextDataNeeded: Priority evidence includes better-preserved cranial/postcranial overlap, robust stratigraphic control, and specimen-linked morphometrics.
researchContext.revisionOutlook: Interpretation is expected to improve as new finds and reanalyses clarify taxonomy and anatomy.
